raw_text:
Blair blasts Tory spending plans
 
 Tony Blair has launched an attack on Conservative spending plans, saying they are a "ludicrous improbability".
 
 The prime minister has told a Labour Party gathering that the Tory policies would cause economic failure. Tory leader Michael Howard has said his party would cut £35bn in "wasteful" spending to allow £4bn in tax cuts. On Saturday, Tory shadow home secretary David Davis said the Tories would fund the cuts by removing "inefficiencies" which had "burgeoned" under Labour. In his speech, Mr Blair contrasted a reformed Labour party, which had learned to occupy the political centre ground, with a hidebound Tory party, which he said would turn the clock back with spending cuts. Mr Blair said: "The Conservative tax and spending proposals would put at risk, both Britain's hard-won economic stability - the lowest mortgages, inflation, unemployment, for decades - and the key investment in public services.
 
 "I believe that the Tory plans are as plain a call to return to the past as it's possible to imagine," he said. "It's a recipe for exactly the same boom and bust economics and cuts in public services that were their hallmark in 18 years of Conservative government." Mr Blair added: "They, the Conservatives have learned nothing." By contrast, he said, New Labour had listened to its electorate and changed.
 
 Mr Blair went on to list his government's achievements and to issue a rallying call to the party. "So now we have a choice, we can defend this record and we can build on it and go on and fulfil the promise or give up and go back. And I say we have to fight." In response, David Davis said the Tories would make cuts, such as removing regional assemblies, but would bring in more police officers and match Labour's spending on health and education. "Everybody knows, having lived through this government the last seven years, that they faced lots of stealth tactics, lots of increases in taxes, but no improvement in public services," he said. Mr Davis said Labour had been responsible for "huge waste, huge overspending, not on the frontline at all but on bureaucracy". "The public face a choice between more waste and more taxes with this government, less waste and lower taxes with a Tory government," he concluded.
 
 Gordon Brown has addressed the conference behind closed doors. The Chancellor said the Conservatives' plans would see some £50bn in spending cuts by 2011, which the Tories deny. Mr Brown also issued call for party unity and warn of the dangers of allowing themselves to be "distracted or diverted". According to an advance text released by officials, he told delegates: "We must all show the strength and unity of purpose to take the long-term decisions necessary to meet them."
 
 Mr Brown warned that the Tories were planning "the biggest cuts ever in the history of any election manifesto". Meanwhile, Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin accused Mr Blair of "misrepresenting" the party's proposals and questioned how Labour would fund its own plans. "He still cannot accept the simple truth, which is that we will spend more on what matters to people - schools, hospitals and police - and that we will offer value for money and lower taxes," Mr Letwin said. "Once again Mr Blair and his Chancellor have failed to answer the question that lies at the heart of this election - which taxes will they put up to fill the £8bn shortfall in their plans?"
llama3.2:1b: Blair attacks Tory spending plans, saying they are a "ludicrous improbability". The Tory party's leader Michael Howard proposes cutting £35bn in "wasteful" spending. Blair responds by contrasting his government with a reformed Labour party that had learned to occupy the political centre ground. He warns of economic failure and cuts in public services if the Tories proceed with their plans. David Davis says the Tories will fund the cuts by removing inefficiencies, while Gordon Brown calls for party unity and warns of the dangers of being distracted.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair attacks Conservative spending plans, saying they are a "ludicrous improbability" that would cause economic failure. He contrasts the Tory party with Labour's reformed approach and says the Tories would cut £35bn in spending but fail to explain how they plan to fund it.
gemma2:2b: Tony Blair criticizes Conservative spending cuts as "ludicrous" and predicts economic failure, contrasting New Labour's reforms with a return to past practices under Tory leadership. He argues that the Conservatives haven't learned from past mistakes.  David Davis defends the Tories' plan for spending cuts and increased police presence, claiming it will provide value-for-money benefits without increasing taxes. Gordon Brown emphasizes party unity and a commitment to long-term solutions while warning of the dangers of distractions and diversions. Oliver Letwin claims that the Conservatives will allocate more funds towards education, healthcare, and policing while also reducing taxes.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Tony Blair criticizes Conservative spending plans, suggesting they are a "ludicrous improbability". Prime minister Blair compares Tory party to Labour's past, calling it a "recipe for exactly the same boom and bust economics and cuts in public services that were their hallmark in 18 years of Conservative government". Mr. Brown says they will cut £50bn by 2011 and warned against allowing Labour to divert funds. Blair and Brown criticize the spending plans as costing more than Labour's 2010 manifesto.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Tony Blair attacks Conservative spending plans, saying they would lead to economic failure and cuts in public services. He contrasts Labour's record of listening to its electorate with a Tory party that has learned nothing from past government policies. Gordon Brown criticizes Conservative proposals for big spending cuts but warns against distraction. The Tories' shadow chancellor accuses Labour of misrepresenting their plans and questioning how they would fund theirs without tax increases.
qwen2.5:3b: Tony Blair criticizes Conservative spending plans, predicting economic failure if implemented. He contrasts a reformed Labour party with a Tory party he claims is clinging to past policies, leading to boom-and-bust economics and cuts in public services. Blair highlights his government's achievements and urges Laborites to defend the record or give up. In response, David Davis argues for spending cuts while maintaining police presence and investment in key sectors. Gordon Brown criticizes Conservative plans, warning of massive spending reductions by 2011. Oliver Letwin questions Labour’s proposals, accusing them of misrepresentation.

The prime minister told a Labour party gathering that the Tory policies would cause economic failure. The Tory leader Michael Howard said his party would cut $35bn in "wasteful" spending to allow £4bn in tax cuts on Saturday. Mr Blair said: "The Conservative tax and spending proposals would put at risk, both Britain's hard-won economic stability - the lowest mortgages, inflation, unemployment, for decades - and the key investment in public services that were their hallmark in 18 years of Conservative government. They, the Conservatives have learned nothing."

By contrast, he said, New Labour had listened to its electorate and changed. He offered a choice, they could defend this record and build on it.

David Davis said the Tories would make cuts, such as removing regional assemblies, but brought in more police officers and matched Labour's spending on health and education. "Everyone knows, having lived through this government the last seven years, that they faced lots of stealth tactics, lots of increases in taxes, but no improvement in public services," he said.

Gordon Brown said: "We must all show the strength and unity of purpose to take the long-term decisions necessary to meet them."

He issued call for party unity and warn of the dangers of allowing themselves to be "distracted or diverted". According to an advance text released by officials, he told delegates: "We must all show the strength and unity of purpose to take the long-term decisions necessary to meet them."
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is:

* The prime minister has launched an attack on Conservative spending plans.
* Tony Blair has told a Labour Party gathering that the Tory policies would cause economic failure.
* Tory leader Michael Howard has said they would cut £35bn in "wasteful" spending to allow £4bn in tax cuts.
* On Saturday, Tory shadow home secretary David Davis said the Tories would fund the cuts by removing "inefficiencies".
* Mr Blair contrasted a reformed Labour party with a hidebound Tory party.
* The prime minister said the Tory plans are as plain a call to return to the past as it's possible to imagine.
* It's a recipe for exactly the same boom and bust economics and cuts in public services that were their hallmark in 18 years of Conservative government.
* Mr Blair went on to list his government's achievements and to issue a rallying call to the party.
* The prime minister said the Tories would make cuts, such as removing regional assemblies, but would bring in more police officers and match Labour's spending on health and education.
* Everybody knows, having lived through this government the last seven years, that they faced lots of stealth tactics, lots of increases in taxes, but no improvement in public services.
* The public face a choice between more waste and more taxes with this government, less waste and lower taxes with a Tory government.
* Gordon Brown has addressed the conference behind closed doors.
* The Chancellor said the Conservatives' plans would see some £50bn in spending cuts by 2011.
* Mr Brown warned that the Tories were planning "the biggest cuts ever" in the history of any election manifesto.
* Mr Letwin accused Mr Blair of misrepresenting the party's proposals and questioning how Labour would fund its own plans.
* The prime minister told delegates: "We must all show the strength and unity of purpose to take the long-term decisions necessary to meet them."
* Mr Letwin said that while the Tories were planning "the biggest cuts ever", they would spend more on what matters to people - schools, hospitals and police - and offer value for money and lower taxes.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Tony Blair and the Conservative spending plans versus Labour's New Labour. Let me read through it carefully.

The first paragraph talks about Blair launching an attack on Conservative spending plans by saying they're absurd and dangerous. He tells a Labour gathering that the Tory policies would cause economic failure because they'd cut £35bn in "wasteful" spending to get £4bn in tax cuts. David Davis said this would come from removing inefficiencies under Labour.

 Blair contrasts the reform led by Labour with a hidden Conservative party. He says the Conservatives haven't learned anything, so their plans are just another "brum". He mentions that the Conservatives have learned nothing and the New Labour is listening to its voters.

 Then Blair lists his government's achievements and tells a rallying call for the party. He mentions the choice between defending the record or building on it and saying they have to fight if they don't keep going. 

 On another page, Gordon Brown addressed the Conservative plans by stating cuts of £50bn by 2011 but the Tories deny this. Brown warned about party unity and the dangers of letting themselves be distracted.

 Then there's a section where Gordon Brown told delegates that we must show strength and unity for long-term decisions to meet their plans. He warned the Tories were planning the biggest cuts ever, while Labour would fund its own plans.

 Finally, Oliver Letwin questioned Blair on how Labour would fund their own proposals, saying he can't accept the idea that they should spend more on people matters and lower taxes.

 Hmm, I need to make sure I capture the key points: Blair's attack on Conservative spending, Labour's reform vs hidden Conservative, political differences leading to the debate, achievements of Blair, warnings from Brown about party unity, and questions about Labour funding their plans.

 Let me structure this into a concise summary without explanations. Start with Blair's launch, mention the cuts by Tories, the contrast between Labour and Tory parties, the warning that they've learned nothing, and then Blair's efforts to defend his record and build on it. Then mention Brown's warnings and the potential cuts. Finally, letwin's questions about Labour's funding.

 Make sure to keep it plain text without any formatting or reasoning.
</think>

Tony Blair launched a criticism of Conservative spending plans by calling them "ludicrous improbability," threatening economic failure. He accused the Tories of cutting £35bn in "wasteful" spending to generate £4bn in tax cuts, suggesting this would be done by removing inefficiencies under Labour. The contrast was between Labour's reform and a hidden Conservative stance, which Blair said had learned nothing. Blair also highlighted achievements but issued a rallying call for the party to defend its record and expand on it. On another page, Gordon Brown warned of potential £50bn cuts by 2011 but called for party unity and tax control. He mentioned Labour's waste and overspending on public services. Oliver Letwin questioned Blair about Labour's funding plans, asking if they would spend more on people matters and offer value for money.
tinyllama:1.1b: The text is a summary of the remarks made by Tony Blair during the Labour Party's annual conference. In it, Blair contrasted a reformed Labour party with a hidebound Conservative government, saying that both have learned nothing and are about to undertake "boom and bus" economic cuts. He also criticized the government's policies, stating that the Conservatives would spend more on schools, hospitals, and police, while offering value for money and lower taxes. Blair called for unity among party members and warned of the danger of allowing oneself to be "distracted or diverged" by election manifestos. The speaker is not specified in the summary text but will likely be Oliver Letwin, a shadow chancellor who accused Blair of misrepresenting Labour's proposals and questioned their funding capacity.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The text you provided is a concise summary of an article discussing the proposed spending cuts by UK's Conservatives and Labour parties. It highlights that Tony Blair, former Prime Minister, believes that the Tories' spending plans are ludicrous and that the Conservatives would cut £35bn in wasteful spending to allow £4bn in tax cuts. The author then compares these plans with those of Labour Party, which has learned from its mistakes and will use a middle ground to avoid economic failure.
phi:2.7b: Tony Blair attacked Conservative spending proposals, saying they would cause economic failure. The prime minister suggested that the Tories were trying to return to the past by making cuts and called for New Labour to continue building on its record of reform. Meanwhile, Gordon Brown addressed the conference behind closed doors and warned against being distracted or diverted from taking long-term decisions. Labour has promised not to increase taxes to fund its plans, while the Conservatives have pledged to cut £35bn in "wasteful" spending and use tax cuts to pay for it. David Davis, the Tory shadow home secretary, said that the party's plans would be funded by removing inefficiencies and that they would still make cuts like Labour did. The conference ended with a warning from Mr Brown about the dangers of division within the Labour Party and a call for unity in order to tackle the challenges ahead.
orca-mini:3b: Tony Blair has slammed Tory spending plans, saying they are a "ludicrous improbability" and compared the party to a past era of Conservative government. The prime minister told a Labour Party gathering that the Tory policies would cause economic failure and urged the party to defend its record and build on it. He also warned of the dangers of allowing themselves to be distracted or diverted. Gordon Brown addressed an internal conference, saying the Tories' plans would see £50bn in spending cuts by 2011 and criticized Tony Blair for misrepresenting their proposals. Meanwhile, Tory shadow home secretary David Davis said his party would fund the cuts by removing "inefficiencies" which had "burgeoned" under Labour.
hermes3:3b: Tony Blair criticizes Conservative spending plans, claiming them as a return to past boom-bust economics. He says Tory policies would risk Britain's economic stability and public services.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Tony Blair criticized Conservative spending plans, calling them "ludicrous improbability" that could risk economic failure and lead to spending cuts in public services. He contrasted New Labour's reformed party with the hidebound Tory party that would turn back time. Mr. Blair highlighted that the Conservative tax and spending proposals were a call to return to the past, similar to their 18 years of government marked by boom and bust economics and cuts in public services.

He argued that the Tories' proposed £35bn spending cuts would lead to a return of "boom and bust" economics. Tory leader Michael Howard defended the cuts, claiming they would eliminate waste and allow for tax reductions while maintaining spending on key services. David Davis accused Labour of wasteful spending and excessive taxation, while Gordon Brown warned that Tory plans would result in £50bn in cuts by 2011, a claim the Conservatives denied. Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin accused Blair of misrepresenting their proposals and questioned how Labour would fund its own plans without raising taxes.
stablelm2:1.6b: Tony Blair criticized Conservative spending plans as "ludicrous improbability," citing potential economic failure. He contrasted a reformed Labour party with a hidebound Tory party, warning that the Conservative tax and spending proposals could return boom and bust economics and cut public services. New Labour has listened to its electorate and changed, while Old Labour faced massive waste and overspending. Gordon Brown warned of the dangers of allowing oneself to be distracted or diverted in addressing long-term decisions necessary to meet challenges. Tory leader Michael Howard pledged £4bn in tax cuts by cutting £bn in "wasteful" spending, and shadow home secretary David Davis proposed removing inefficiencies to fund the cuts.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Tony Blair criticizes Conservative spending plans, deeming them a "ludicrous improbability" and a recipe for economic instability, boom-and-bust cycles, and reduced public services. He contrasts New Labour's reformed party with the Tories' inability to learn from past mistakes, emphasizing Labour's focus on reducing waste and improving public services. Blair highlights his government's achievements and calls for continued progress.

Conservative shadow home secretary David Davis counters by outlining planned spending cuts, including removal of regional assemblies and increased police officers, while matching Labour's expenditure on health and education. He accuses Labour of excessive bureaucracy and inefficient public spending.

Chancellor Gordon Brown, addressing the conference privately, warns of potentially "the biggest cuts ever" in Tory manifestos by 2011, calling for unity within the party to take long-term decisions. Shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin refutes Blair's critique, asserting that the Conservatives will invest more in essential services and offer better value for money at lower tax rates, questioning Labour's funding strategy for their plans.
reference: In his speech, Mr Blair contrasted a reformed Labour party, which had learned to occupy the political centre ground, with a hidebound Tory party, which he said would turn the clock back with spending cuts.Tory leader Michael Howard has said his party would cut £35bn in "wasteful" spending to allow £4bn in tax cuts.Mr Blair said: "The Conservative tax and spending proposals would put at risk, both Britain's hard-won economic stability - the lowest mortgages, inflation, unemployment, for decades - and the key investment in public services.The Chancellor said the Conservatives' plans would see some £50bn in spending cuts by 2011, which the Tories deny.Meanwhile, Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin accused Mr Blair of "misrepresenting" the party's proposals and questioned how Labour would fund its own plans.On Saturday, Tory shadow home secretary David Davis said the Tories would fund the cuts by removing "inefficiencies" which had "burgeoned" under Labour.The prime minister has told a Labour Party gathering that the Tory policies would cause economic failure.In response, David Davis said the Tories would make cuts, such as removing regional assemblies, but would bring in more police officers and match Labour's spending on health and education.Mr Davis said Labour had been responsible for "huge waste, huge overspending, not on the frontline at all but on bureaucracy"."Once again Mr Blair and his Chancellor have failed to answer the question that lies at the heart of this election - which taxes will they put up to fill the £8bn shortfall in their plans?"
